repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Add `embedsignature.pure` compiler directive to generate pure-Python type annotations compatible with type hinting syntax. This mostly amounts to:
* Not emitting C type declarations in signatures.
* Preferring explicit argument type annotations over C types.
* Mapping C type names to the closest Python type name.

See https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3150

comment_data.body:
This probably breaks the type check in fused types, removing support for `long` in Py2:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/236e705d644247415baacf0a6d38b6e85379cce1/Cython/Compiler/FusedNode.py#L296-L304

There are other usages of the method, but this is the only one that I could find that breaks. Thus, special-casing `int` in the fused types type checking code seems a reasonable fix. It would also make the `py_type_name()` method cleaner again.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,6 +54,9 @@ def __init__(self, context):
         self.class_name = None
         self.class_node = None
 
+    def _select_format(self, embed, clinic):
+        return embed

comment_data.body:
That's for a future enhancement I was planning. I should have added a comment about this.

The idea is to support the `__text_signature__` function attribute you get from Python's argument clinic to support `inspect.signature()`. But this would only be useful if setting explicitly the compiler option `binding = False`, otherwise Cython functions work just fine with `inspect.signature()`.

On a second thought, I may very well get rid of this thing. What would be your preference?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,6 +54,9 @@ def __init__(self, context):
         self.class_name = None
         self.class_node = None
 
+    def _select_format(self, embed, clinic):
+        return embed

comment_data.body: If it's not needed for this PR, let's leave it out.

comment_data.body: The test in this like makes sure a Python 2 `long` is properly dispatched.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -401,6 +401,40 @@ def test_cython_numeric(cython.numeric arg):
     """
     print cython.typeof(arg), arg
 
+
+cdef fused int_t:
+    int
+
+cdef _test_pylong(int_t i):
+    print cython.typeof(i)
+
+def test_pylong(int_t i):
+    """
+    >>> import cython
+    >>> try:    long = long # Python 2
+    ... except: long = int  # Python 3
+
+    >>> test_pylong[int](int(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](int(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(int(0))
+    int
+
+    >>> test_pylong[int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(long(0))

comment_data.body: I had the suspicion I was breaking something. I did my best to address this issue. Let's continue the discussion in the other two comments I added after my changes. I'm resolving this one.
This is my attempt to support int/long under Python 2. Does it look good enough?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -293,8 +293,12 @@ def _fused_instance_checks(self, normal_types, pyx_code, env):
         """
         for specialized_type in normal_types:
             # all_numeric = all_numeric and specialized_type.is_numeric
+            py_type_name = specialized_type.py_type_name()
+            if py_type_name == 'int':
+                # Support Python 2 long
+                py_type_name = '(int, long)'

comment_data.body: I removed the method and left some `# clinic: xxx` comments to keep around what should be used for the argument clinic format.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -54,6 +54,9 @@ def __init__(self, context):
         self.class_name = None
         self.class_node = None
 
+    def _select_format(self, embed, clinic):
+        return embed

@@ -293,8 +293,12 @@ def _fused_instance_checks(self, normal_types, pyx_code, env):
         """
         for specialized_type in normal_types:
             # all_numeric = all_numeric and specialized_type.is_numeric
+            py_type_name = specialized_type.py_type_name()
+            if py_type_name == 'int':
+                # Support Python 2 long
+                py_type_name = '(int, long)'

comment_data.body:
I never considered having both a C type declaration and a Python type declaration for the same argument. Not sure if it's a good idea to allow (and even encourage) that. I can see in your test examples that it works (apparently), and I can see it being useful in order to disambiguate C type declarations. However, we're currently trying to discourage C type declarations in favour of type annotations in Python syntax, and this counters that.

```suggestion
``embedsignature.pure`` (True / False)
    If set to True, Cython will do its best attempt to use
    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures.  If arguments
    have explicit Python type annotations, these are preferred over C type
    declarations.  Otherwise, declared C types are mapped to the closest
    Python type equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python ``int`` type
    and C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type). 
    Implies ``embedsignature=True``.  Default is False.

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,14 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.pure`` (True / False)
+    If set to True, Cython will do a its best attempt to use
+    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures. If arguments
+    have explicit type annotations, these are preferred over C
+    types. Otherwise, C types are mapped to the closest Python type
+    equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python ``int`` type and
+    C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).  Default is False.
+

comment_data.body:
I don't think the `cdef` function is of any use here. There is no internal dispatch since both functions use the same fused type.
```suggestion
def test_pylong(int_t i):
    """
    >>> import cython
    >>> try:    long = long # Python 2
    ... except: long = int  # Python 3

    >>> test_pylong[int](int(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](int(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong(int(0))
    int

    >>> test_pylong[int](long(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](long(0))
    int
    >>> test_pylong(long(0))
    int

    >>> test_pylong[cython.long](0)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
    Traceback (most recent call last):
    KeyError: ...
    """
    print(cython.typeof(i))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -401,6 +401,40 @@ def test_cython_numeric(cython.numeric arg):
     """
     print cython.typeof(arg), arg
 
+
+cdef fused int_t:
+    int
+
+cdef _test_pylong(int_t i):
+    print cython.typeof(i)
+
+def test_pylong(int_t i):
+    """
+    >>> import cython
+    >>> try:    long = long # Python 2
+    ... except: long = int  # Python 3
+
+    >>> test_pylong[int](int(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](int(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(int(0))
+    int
+
+    >>> test_pylong[int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.int](long(0))
+    int
+    >>> test_pylong(long(0))
+    int
+
+    >>> test_pylong[cython.long](0)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
+    Traceback (most recent call last):
+    KeyError: ...
+    """
+    _test_pylong(i)

comment_data.body:
Remember that "Python type declarations" are actually just annotations. 

If you want to reject arguments with both C types and annotations, you will make my life miserable, I'll have a lot of work to do in mpi4py to accomodate for that change, to the point that you would force me to remove all C types form arguments of `def` functions. 

Moreover, your call will prevent users for doing some very reasonable stuff, For example

```python
def foo(int arg: Annotated[int, MaxValueAllowed(42)]) -> Any:
    ...
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -854,6 +854,14 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     signature, which cannot otherwise be retrieved after
     compilation.  Default is False.
 
+``embedsignature.pure`` (True / False)
+    If set to True, Cython will do a its best attempt to use
+    pure-Python type annotations in embedded signatures. If arguments
+    have explicit type annotations, these are preferred over C
+    types. Otherwise, C types are mapped to the closest Python type
+    equivalent (e.g., C ``short`` is mapped to Python ``int`` type and
+    C ``double`` is mapped to Python ``float`` type).  Default is False.
+

commit.message:
Enhancements to autodoc/embedsignature

Add `embedsignature.pure` compiler directive to generate pure-Python
type annotations compatible with type hinting syntax.
This mostly amounts to:
* Not emitting C type declarations in signatures.
* Preferring explicit argument type annotations over C types.
* Mapping C type names to the closest Python type name.
